Legal_Issue: Whether the Plaintiffs can obtain an interim injunction for alleged patent infringement
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimony on irreparable harm in Australia; lack of evidence on urgency in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Interim injunction granted for Australia; denied for Canada
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff bears burden to satisfy RJR-Macdonald test
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony deemed credible for Australian market harm
Legal_Rule: RJR-Macdonald test: (a) serious issue to be tried, (b) irreparable harm, (c) balance of convenience
Procedural_Issue: Urgency not established for Canadian market
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of Canadian Patent No. 1,341,196 through manufacturing, selling, and exporting perindopril
Review_Standard: Balance of convenience, irreparable harm, serious issue to be tried
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Both parties presented evidence; Defendants provided 12-day notice undertaking
Key_Evidence_Considered: Expert testimony on market impact in Australia; Defendants' marketing approval status in Canada
Legal_Framework: Canadian patent law, interim injunctive relief framework
Applicant_Challenge: Establishing urgency and irreparable harm in Canada
Court_Result: Injunction granted for Australia, not for Canada
Legal_Rule_Source: RJR-Macdonald test from Federal Court jurisprudence
Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities for interim relief
Defendant_Response: Provided 12-day notice undertaking not to launch in Canada without notice
Remedy_Requested: Interim injunction to prevent export and sale of perindopril
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of infringing activities pending trial
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial determination on interim injunction motion
Legal_Provision: Section 44 of the Federal Courts Act
Rule 374 of the Federal Court Rules
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Alleged infringement of Canadian Patent No. 1,341,196
Applicable_Process: Motion for interim injunction under Federal Court Rules
